text: [Music]
I live right outside of Boston I live
about five miles away so it's a real
inner suburb it's it's not a phenomenon
that you could really find in New York
we have a small town that's that close
to uh the city you know and and I and I
really find that to be a nice way to
live um because you have you know the
best of both worlds in a sense um the
thing I've been really thinking about
lately
um was what what happened with gas
prices um over the summer when they
spiked up to $4 a gallon you know
they've since dropped because we're in
the midst of this financial crisis but
at that time I was thinking very um
frequently
about in in the Boston area if you
wanted to buy a house for under say
$300,000 um you'd have to move out of
the city maybe like 45 minutes
and you had a long commute and I know
there are people outside of La who do
this as well outside of every major city
outside of Atlanta you know um you have
to drive 45 minutes to an hour or more
both ways you know to get to and from
work and I really felt like uh we're on
the verge
of that whole Suburban lifestyle being
economically untenable um that they're
going to be these distant and I think
you know some planners have been talking
about this they're going to be these
suburbs that are in effect going to be
like inner city ghettos you know they're
going to be abandoned and they're going
to become uh you know they going to be h
a couple houses that are inhabited on A
Street full of you know boarded up big
old homes you know it it may be a
dystopian Vision that is um too extreme
but you can see how that that could
happen and you can see um you know the
values of homes near the city and near
public transportation shooting up and
the Valu of homes um you know a half
hour or more from the city you know
really plummeting and and um you know
just a big demographic shakeup in our
culture and and a lot of anger um I
think you know you you you can see the
beginnings of it in terms of people you
know realizing they can't drive their
SUVs and um you know people realizing
that they built homes that were too big
I mean I think it's going to seem um
pretty shocking you know 50 or 100 years
down the line for people to think that
in the 1990s and you know early 2000 um
people were building these gigantic
houses and driving these gigantic cars
even though they knew that uh you know
it wasn't sustainable economically that
we just didn't have the oil to you know
to do it
